contextId.occurrenceNote: How the people of Israel treated the poor is compared to how people step heavily on the ground (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They trample on the heads of the poor as people trample on dust on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares his judgment on the people of Israel to crushing them with something very heavy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I will crush you as a cart that is full of grain can crush someone

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Lord compares the people of Israel being rescued with an unsuccessful attempt to rescue an animal from a lion. They will not be completely rescued. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As the shepherd rescues ... so will the people of Israel ... be rescued

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "break out like a fire" represents destroying things as fire destroys things. Alternate translation: "he will become like a fire that breaks out suddenly and destroys everything" or "he will destroy everything like a fire" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he will break out like fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents causing there to be much justice and righteous. Alternate translation: "let there be so much justice that it is like flowing water, and let there be so much righteousness that it is like a constantly flowing stream" or "let justice abound like a flood, and let righteousness abound like a stream that never stops" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: let justice flow like water, and righteousness like a constantly flowing stream

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos compares the rising and sinking of the waters of the Nile River to how Yahweh will cause the land to shake when he judges the people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: All of it will rise up like the Nile River ... like the river of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the River" and "river of Egypt" both refer to the Nile river. Yahweh causing the land to shake violently is compared to the waters of the Nile river rising and sinking. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: all of it will rise up like the River, and sink again like the river of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The picture here is of grain falling through the sieve and stones being kept out. The idea is that Yahweh will remove all of the sinful people from Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I will shake the house of Israel ... as one shakes grain in a sieve, so that not the smallest stone will fall to the ground
